climbs.name: The Tomb of the Unknown Shoulder

content.description: Start between Guillotine and Jackknife. Climb wall left of small crack between the two climbs
content.location: Outlook Rocks area. Start between Guillotine and Jackknife.

content.description: Fun rock to boulder around on.
content.protection: Use a long static line for a TR
content.location: Upstream end of Outlook Rocks. Right on the river

content.protection: Pads, now, guts and finger strength then.
content.location: 75 m SW of Jan's Face, upstream. SW. Just right of "Jack Knife”.

content.description: Super short boulder if you can even call it that just fun thing to maybe warm up on or if your just bored
content.location: From the bottom of outlook rock looking at the river go right until you are the hiking trial.

content.protection: 1 pad for the tree at the end
content.location: Start at the Potomac River and traverse north, right. 15m left of Jackknife.

content.description: This is a boulder that's basically the backside of the highest point of Outlook Rocks.  I'm not sure if it has a name or named routes but clearly bouldering  has been going on here.  If anyone would like to pass on info then that would be great.  There are maybe two main ways up this boulder on the left side and the right.  The right side route has a sit start variation that makes it a good bit harder.  The crux on either side is down low and then if get's juggy towards the top.
content.location: On the back side of the highest point of Outlook Rocks.  This is at the far west side of the main Carderock area right near the river where the big bend around the west end of Vaso Island is.  You can see the C&O Canal trail from here as well.

content.description: Climb the left end of the rock. Stat the same as Lembecks

Outlook Rock, central. Unmistakable line, following an incipient crack up the middle of the face above a square cut overhang. Disused, once a favorite of 1980's climbers looking to escape crowds, now a bit lichenous. But a nice place down on the river.
content.location: Central Outlook Rock. Right, downstream of Nose that Goes. Unmistakable line following an incipient crack up the middle of the face above a square cut overhang. The Nose That Blows can be referred to top rope climbs left and right of thin crack as well.

content.description: Near the water downriver from the Daisy face.   Climb the layback corner. A variation to the left in the finger corner can also be done (5.10).
content.location: In the Outlook Rocks area, downstream from Daisy Face.

content.description: At the left side of Jackknife/Guillotine crag, high on a platform ledge and very near the corner is a short wall with a classic, slabby highball. Grab a flexi-flake and paste the feet and yank to crimps V4, end on jug ledge. Don’t bust the low grips and fall off the platform!
content.protection: Ground up highball with fragile holds and light spice. Pad and spotter or solo grip
content.location: Left side of Jackknife/Guillotine crag, high on a platform ledge, very near the corner is a short wall with a classic, slabby highball with a flexible flake start.  Start 12 m right, NE, of the crux of River Traverse V7 and 11 meters left of Jacknife

content.description: Start same as The Nose That Goes. Follow crack up and right.
Start at rocks upstream from the main 'Outlook Rocks' area.    Climb anywhere on the low angle face.   Climbs vary from 5.6 to 5.8.   Great slab like (low angle) climbing which is kinda rare in area.
content.location: Carderock, MD (upper parkinglot).   Start at rocks upstream from the main 'Outlook Rocks' area.

content.description: Layback or jam your way up the obvious right leaning crack to jugs at the top.
content.location: Behind (toward river) the Outlook Rocks Boulder, but stay on the high ground.

content.description: Start: Small inside corner on the wall facing the river.    After working the feet up, the climb is done as a layback without using the diagonal crack on the right. It is also possible to climb the face to the right of the corner crack (5.8-5.9).
content.location: The Outlook Rocks area. Downstream of Lazy Daisy.

content.description: Start four feet upstream from Jackknife between two vertical cracks.   Climb the face between the two cracks to an upside-down flake. The climb has also been called the upside down climb
Super easy just like the one to the right of it
content.location: Right next to short stack. Follow the river going up stream along the trail it will be on your right

content.description: Rakkup says that the crux is the last eight feet of the climb, but to me, it felt like the beginning of the climb was the crux.
content.protection: There are a few trees at the top. You could probably also build an anchor with trad gear.
content.location: Lembeck's Rock sector of Outlook Rocks. The climb is located at the right side of Lembeck's Rock left of Lembeck's Crossover. The arete is off route.

content.description: Beautiful, short, right-facing lie back corner above, river. Finger tips corner at river level. Possible to use as DWS in high water, swift water, but best to wait for low water and top rope, lead or solo. 12m
content.location: Left of Stannards Playground at Overlook Rock, Carderock, MD. Just left of "River Traverse" at river level. Right, downstream of the Nose that Blows.

content.description: Upstream end of Carderock near the Vaso Island Crossing. A major bend in the river has exposed resilient blunt faces of shist. Less visited than the rest of Carderock, Outlook Rocks is a good place to get away from the crowds and onto less traveled rock.  Adventure top roping and bouldering on decent, short lines is name of the game.  As the rocks rise of out of the river, access is more difficult, isolating the sub-sectors.  Check out the open face of Nose that Blows, the moderate corner of Jackknife or the hard boulders around Stannard’s Playground. A quiet place on the river.
